State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization Taiyuan University of Technology No. 79 Yingze West Street Taiyuan 030024 China A series of copper catalysts with loading less than 1.0 wt% supported on super activated carbon (SAC, 2403 m2·g−1) as well as commercial activated carbon (AC, 1297 m2·g−1) were produced by the wet-impregnation process and applied in methanol oxidative carbonylation to generate dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst showed highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles (NPs, ∼2.2 nm) and exhibited a turnover frequency (44.6 h−1) about four times higher than that of 0.5Cu/AC. The characterization results indicate that the large specific surface area of SAC greatly promoted the dispersion of Cu NPs. In addition, the abundant oxygen-containing groups on SAC enhanced interaction between Cu NPs and carbon support, which maintained the concentration of active Cu0 sites and facilitated high stability of Cu/SAC catalysts during the reaction. This research provided a novel strategy for fabricating low loading Cu-based catalysts with commercial prospects for the DMC synthesis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol carbonylation Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) Super activated carbon (SAC) Ultra-low loading Cu catalysts Data Availability I have shared the link to my data at the Attach File step. 1 Introduction Due to its great biodegradability, solubility and low toxicity, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has received a lot of consideration as a broadly utilized chemical intermediate. DMC has been adopted as a nontoxic solvent, a phosgene substitute, and an intermediary in the manufacture of polycarbonates, isocyanates [1,2], and various chemicals [3,4]. As the main raw material composition of lithium battery electrolyte, the demand for DMC has entered the explosive growth stage along with the global new energy revolution set off in recent years [5–7]. The oxidative carbonylation of methanol (MeOH) has been recognized as the most proposed potential method with merits of the high carbon source utilization rate and environmental advantages among the numerous DMC synthesis pathways [8–10]. The two main categories of the catalysts examined for this reaction are chlorine [11,12] and chlorine-free ones [13]. Chlorine-containing catalysts suffered from serious equipment corrosion, catalyst deactivation and products purity [14]. Reversely, chlorine-free catalytic systems avoided the above problems and showed the outstanding advantage of easy separation from products, which has aroused great interest of researchers [15–19]. Among them, carbon-supported copper catalysts (Cu/C) have become one of the most appreciated catalysts in view of the variety of supports and excellent catalytic performance [20–22]. Different carbon materials including nanotubes, nanofiber, and aerogels supported copper catalysts were widely used in oxidations [23], Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [24], hydrogenations [25], dehydrogenations [26] and coupling reactions [27] etc. In order to peruse high catalytic activity, it is of great challenge to ensure that Cu NPs own a very small original size and remain stable during the reaction system for the above catalysts [28]. In the oxidative carbonylation of MeOH, several strategies were available for this purpose as follows: adopting high specific surface area supports such as hollow carbon spheres (HCS) [29] and mesoporous carbon materials [18], enhancing the surface functional groups of carbon supports (oxygen-containing groups, OCGs) [30], sulfonic acid groups [19]) as well as introducing N species into carbon supports [15]. Activated carbon (AC) is a recognized material with highly developed internal pores and large specific surface area [31]. The Dow Company explored the effect of various supports on the performance of copper-based catalyst for the oxidative carbonylation of methanol and found that the catalyst supported on AC was significantly better than that supported on metal oxide in selectivity and reaction activity [6]. Additionally, it was confirmed that altering the surface area [32], acidic sites [33], OCGs [34], pore structure, and microcrystalline structures [35] of AC-supported copper catalysts could further increase their catalytic efficiency. However, since the specific surface area of AC prepared by conventional means is relatively low, only about 1000–1500 m2·g−1 [36], the dispersion of active metals is greatly restricted. In recent years, super activated carbon (SAC) with ultra-high specific surface area higher than 2000 m2·g−1 prepared from asphalt, petroleum coke, and biochar and used as electrode materials for super-capacitors [37], electrode modifiers and [38], CO2 capture [39] etc. Especially, the SAC showed superior properties as catalysts or supporting materials in the traditional catalysis and electrocatalysis fields. Ou et al. [40] reported metal-free, carbon-based oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalyst owned the boosted activity in that the ultrahigh specific surface area (up to 2251 m2·g−1) could expose more doping active sites. Puskás et al. [41] prepared mesoporous carbon-supported (2250 m2·g−1) Pd NPs that demonstrated a remarkable catalytic activity with TOF of 14 s−1 in hydrogenation of cyclohexene. Li and coworkers [42] fabricated ultrathin N-doped carbon nanosheet (2105 m2·g−1) supported Co catalyst for direct catalytic oxidation of benzene to phenol and considered that the excellent performance was attributed to more active sites on the catalyst surface accessible to reactants. It is of great significance to reduce the usage of active metals for the development of commercial catalysts considering the production cost. More important, adopting a low-loading level was recently found to be effectively decrease the grain size and improve the dispersion degree of active metals for supported catalysts, which even showed the activity equivalent to that of high loading catalysts [15,43]. The ultra-low Ru loading (0.07–3.0 wt%) on γ-Al2O3 catalysts with grain size of 2.3–4.0 nm were obtained by Simakov et al. [44] using sonication-assisted impregnation and demonstrated good catalytic activity in low temperature methane steam reforming. Zhang et al. [45] developed Cu-SA/HCNS (porous carbon hollow g-C4N4 spheres) catalysts with 0.85 wt% Cu content that showed superior catalytic properties compared to the higher loading catalysts (3.0 wt%). The excellent activity could be attributed to the high dispersion of Cu atoms with an ultra-low loading level. Cuello-Penaloza's group [46] reported that the Cu/MgAl catalysts (0.1–0.6 wt%) were more conducive to the improvement of high selectivity towards alcohols, esters, aldehydes, ketones and other products than the high loading catalysts. In this paper, the xCu/SAC catalysts with low Cu loading level (0.3–1.0 wt%) were prepared by the wet impregnation process using a super pitch-based porous carbon with the large specific surface area (>2000 m2·g−1) as support and used for oxidative carbonylation of methanol, the commercial AC were adopted for comparison as well. A comprehensive characterization methods and catalytic tests were employed to explore the structure and catalytic performance of the Cu/SAC catalysts, and thus to better understand the reaction mechanism of carbon supported copper catalysts for producing DMC. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation (1) Preparation of SAC supports The SAC were prepared from coal liquefaction asphaltene by KNO3 oxidation and KOH activation method [47,48]. (2) Synthesis of xCu/SAC and 0.5Cu/AC catalysts xCu/SAC catalysts with different Cu loadings (x = 0.3, 0.5 and 1.0 wt.%) were prepared by a wet-impregnation method. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and SAC powder were ultrasonically dispersed in deionized water at 30 °C for 40 min. After that, the solvent was evaporated by stirring at 80 °C, followed by drying overnight at 80 °C and then calcination at 400 °C for 2 h with N2/H2 mixture. In addition, the 0.5Cu/AC catalyst supported on commercial AC support (purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd) was prepared by the same method for comparison. 2.2 Characterization techniques The contents of the OCGs on SAC were characterized using Boehm's titration and compared with AC. On a Rigaku D/Max 2500 target diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), powder X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded. According to the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, the catalysts’ specific surface area, average pore diameter, and pore volume were examined in the Beishide apparatus, model 3H-2000PS2. The content of copper in the catalyst was determined by American Agilent 720 ICP-OES. The Raman spectra was acquired on the RM2000 Raman spectrometer of Renishaw, UK. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and H2-N2O titration were used on the Tianjin Xianquan company's TP-5080 automated multipurpose adsorption equipment to assess the dispersion of active copper on the catalyst surface. For H2-TPR, 50 mg samples were treated with Ar at 300 °C for 30 min to remove physiosorbed moisture. Then, the samples were reduced in 5 vol% H2/Ar at a heating rate of 10 °C /min up to 550 °C. For H2-N2O, samples were reduced by H2/Ar at 550 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min for 2 h, and the consumed H2 was denoted as X. After cooling to room temperature, N2O/Ar was introduced for 0.5 h to oxidize surface Cu atoms to Cu2O. The Cu2O was then reduced again with H2, and the quantity of hydrogen consumed was denoted as Y. The dispersion (DCu) was derived from Eq. (1): (1) D Cu = 2 Y X × 100 % TEM images were obtained on Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM, JSM-2100F). The field emission high-resolution transmission electron microscope TALOS F200 underwent STEM and mapping testing. A monochromatic Al Kα radiation source-equipped VG Escalab 250 electron spectrometer was used to obtain the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 2.3 Catalyst activity evaluation The reaction was performed in stainless-steel high-pressure reactor, 5 mL of methanol and a moderate number of catalysts were added. Until the required CO and O2 was up to a certain proportion, the reaction started and carried on for 1.5 h. After that, the mixture in the autoclave was cooled and centrifuged to obtain clarified liquid. Consequently, the precipitate was cleaned with methanol, vacuum-dried, and then put through the aforementioned-procedures for a cycle test. The resulting clarified liquid was fed into the GC-950 gas chromatographic for qualitative and quantitative analysis. Methyl formate (MF) and dimethoxymethane (DMM) as byproducts were detected. The conversion rate of methanol (CMeOH, %), the selectivity of principal and by-products (SDMC, SDMM, SMF, %), space-time yield of DMC (STYDMC, mg⋅(g⋅h)−1) and the turnover frequency (TOF, h−1) were calculated as follows: (1a) C MeOH = 2 × n DMC + 3 × n DMM + 2 × n MF 2 × n DMC + 3 × n DMM + 2 × n MF + n MeOH × 100 % (2) S DMC = 2 × n DMC 2 × n DMC + 3 × n DMM + 2 × n MF × 100 % (3) S DMM = 3 × n DMM 2 × n DMC + 3 × n DMM + 2 × n MF × 100 % (4) S MF = 2 × n MF 2 × n DMC + 3 × n DMM + 2 × n MF × 100 % ST Y DMC = m DMC m cat × t (5) = V MeOH × ρ MeOH × c MeOH × S DMC × M DMC 2 × M MeOH × 1 m cat × t (6) TOF = n DMC n Cu × t Wherein, mDMC: mass of DMC (g); mcat: mass of catalyst (g); VMeOH: volume of MeOH in reaction (mL); ρMeOH: density of MeOH (g⋅mL−1); t: reaction time (h); nX: the molar amount of X (X=DMC, DMM and MF) (mol). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Oxidative carbonylation of methanol 3.1.1 Catalytic activity Table 1 illustrates the catalytic activity of the Cu/SAC and 0.5Cu/AC catalysts in the oxidative carbonylation of methanol. A detailed catalytic result of 0.5Cu/SAC with varied Cu concentration in the DMC synthesis is displayed in Table 2 . Regarding CMeOH and SDMC, the Cu/SAC catalysts displayed higher activity than 0.5Cu/AC, and the highest activity with STYDMC of 316 mg·g−1·h−1 and TOF of 44.6 h−1 was obtained over 0.5Cu/SAC. In addition, it can be observed that the 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst displayed equivalent or even higher activity compared with other carbon supported copper catalysts with high loadings (5.6–10.0 wt%) [15,49,50]. The catalytic performance of 0.5Cu/SAC in the DMC synthesis at different reaction temperatures was measured and collected Table 3 . It was shown that CMeOH first climbed up until 9.4% at 120 °C and then declined with further rising temperature. The methanol conversion is limited at low reaction temperature mostly because of the sluggish reaction rate, whereas the DMC selectivity is relatively high due to the restrictions for the side reactions. However, the side reactions increased to form methylal with the temperature increasing, leading to the decrease of DMC selectivity. That's why the highest selectivity was obtained at 70 °C, which was consistent with the results in our previous work [51]. In addition, no significant variation was observed on the DMC selectivity as the reaction temperature rises from 90 to 130 °C. The 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst showed the best activity with the STY of 316 mg·g−1·h−1 (TOF = 44.6 h−1) at the temperature of 120 °C. Compared the data shown in Table 1, 0.5Cu/SAC displayed superior activity than the commercial CuCl [29] and Cu-based catalysts [34,49] reported in previous studies, regardless of the copper loadings decreased even higher than tenfold. 3.1.2 Catalyst stability The stability of the 0.5Cu/SAC and 0.5Cu/AC catalysts in the oxidative carbonylation of methanol was investigated with 5 recycling reaction at 120 °C, as shown in Fig. 1 . After five cycles, the catalytic activity of 0.5Cu/SAC did not decrease significantly, with approximately 10.4% deactivation in STY, dramatically lower than 0.5Cu/AC catalysts (60.2%) and the Cu@HCS catalysts (50.2%) that reported in previous literature [29]. With the increase of cycle times, the gradual decline of reactivity is may be caused by the loss or agglomeration of Cu species [52,53]. In the presence of reactants CO and O2, the state of Cu components may change and even loss of some Cu species occurred under the condition of high temperature agitation in the liquid phase reaction, which would cause a gradual decrease in catalytic performance. 3.2 Physical and chemical properties of AC and SAC The pore size distribution curves and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of AC and SAC are illustrated in Fig. 2 , and Table 4 lists the related physical characteristics. Two kinds of carbon support were all compliance with the mixed characteristics of typical type I of micropore and typical type IV of mesopore, indicative they are hierarchical pore materials [54]. However, the shape of the hysteresis loop evidence predominantly presence of “cylindrical” mesopores in SAC and “ink-bottle” ones in AC [55]. In addition, it is clearly observed from Fig. 2b both AC and SAC show the narrow pore size distribution, which are mainly concentrated at about 2 nm. Significantly, SAC possesses a higher specific surface area (2403 m2·g−1) and smaller average pore size (1.87 nm) (Table 4), which is very different from that of AC. Raman spectra of AC and SAC shows in Fig. 3 (a) contain two obvious characteristic peaks near 1360 and 1600 cm−1, namely D peak, and G peak, respectively. The stretching vibration of sp2 atom pairs in the carbon chain and ring is responsible for the G peak. while the D peak is attributed to the vibration peak of disordered structure which destroyed the structural symmetry [56]. The ID/IG value is calculated from the intensity ratio of D peak to G peak in Fig. 3(a) were 0.71 and 0.74 for AC and SAC, respectively, indicative of the presence of the smaller graphitization degree and the more defect sites on the surface of SAC than that of AC [57,58]. FT-IR spectra of AC and SAC in Fig. 3(b) showed the peaks at 3425, 1615 and 1074 cm−1 which can be attributed to OH stretching vibration absorption peak [59,60], C=O stretching vibration absorption peak [61], and CO stretching vibration, respectively. Therefore, it is known that both AC and SAC possessed several kinds of OCGs. The quantitative analysis of OCGs on the AC and SAC was performed by Boehm's titration and the results were collected in Table 5 . It is noticeable that the concentration of various OCGs is very different, and SAC has roughly twice as many carboxyl functional groups as AC does. 3.3 Structural properties of Cu/AC and xCu/SAC catalysts 3.3.1 Texture and crystal phase properties N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm in Fig. 2 shows that all the Cu-based catalysts presented the similar isotherm curves as the corresponding support. As compared with AC and SAC supports, there are a decrease in the specific surface area and pore volume of the resulting catalysts with increasing Cu loading as shown in Table 4, which is closely related to copper dispersion. Notably, the specific surface area of 0.5Cu/SAC (2267 m2·g−1) is far larger than that of 0.5Cu/AC catalyst (1242 m2·g−1). The actual copper concentration of Cu/AC and xCu/SAC catalysts are determined by ICP and listed in Table 4. The actual loading of copper is consistent with the calculated results, indicating that the loss of copper in the preparation procedure is almost negligible. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of reduced 0.5Cu/AC and xCu/SAC catalysts. All samples are normalized with the characteristic diffraction peak of amorphous carbon at 24.5°–25° (002) and 43.2° (100) as the standard, which can be assigned to disordered carbon structure [62]. As for the Cu/SAC catalysts, no diffraction peaks of Cu species can be observed with the loading level rises from 0.3wt% to 1.0 wt%. Whereas, the 0.5Cu/AC catalyst exhibits a distinct diffraction peak at 43.3 °corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of metallic Cu (JCPDS: 65–90265) [27], indicating that the Cu precursor was reduced to metallic copper after calcination in the N2/H2 mixture [63]. Therefore, it can be known that the Cu/SAC catalysts showed a much higher Cu dispersion than 0.5Cu/AC [64]. 3.3.2 TEM and STEM TEM images of 0.5Cu/AC and xCu/SAC catalysts along with the corresponding particle size distribution histograms are shown in Fig. 5 . In all cases, a uniform distribution of Cu NPs on the surface of carbon supports can be observed. The average size of Cu NPs increases from 2.0 to 3.3 nm with the rise of Cu loading from 0.3 wt% to 1.0 wt% in the Cu/SAC catalysts. It is noted that the average grain size of Cu species on the surface of 0.5Cu/SAC (2.2 nm) is much smaller than that of 0.5Cu/AC (5.2 nm). In addition, zero-valent copper species exist in the 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst, in that lattice spacing about 0.21 nm as shown in Fig. 5 was attributed to the (111) crystal face of the cubic Cu structure. The Cu dispersion in different catalysts was determined by H2-N2O titration and shown in Table 4. Obviously, the Cu dispersion of the Cu/SAC catalysts are 3∼4 times higher than that of 0.5Cu/AC, and attains the maximum value of 31.5% with the Cu loading of 0.5 wt%, which can be attributed to the special surface properties of SAC support. Also, the element mapping of 0.5Cu/SAC shown in Fig. 6 displayed the evenly distributed blue dots, further confirming highly dispersion of Cu species on the SAC support. 3.3.3 H2-TPR H2-TPR characterization illustrates the strength of the interaction between the support and copper species in 0.5Cu/AC and 0.5Cu/SAC catalysts, and the result curves were shown in Fig. 7 . Both catalysts showed obvious broad peaks in the temperature range of 200–500 °C, which were attributed to the reduction peaks of the active component Cu species from CuO to Cu2O and Cu [18,65]. Specifically, the 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst exhibited the reduction temperature at the range of 350–470 °C remarkably higher than that of 0.5Cu/AC at 250 °C, indicating stronger support-metal interaction and higher copper dispersion [66], which was consistent with the TEM and responsible for the enhanced stability of the 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst. 3.3.4 XPS Fig. 8 a presents XPS spectra of the xCu/SAC and 0.5Cu/AC catalysts. In all cases, there are two signal peaks with centers at ∼933.1 and ∼935.1 eV, which are corresponding to the binding energies (BE) of (Cu0 + Cu+) and Cu2+, respectively [16]. In Table 6 , the typical peak positions and concentration of various copper species are listed. Compared with 0.5Cu/AC (932.5 eV), the characteristic peaks of Cu0 and Cu+ species in the xCu/SAC catalysts (933.1 eV) are shifted to high BE with a maximum value of 0.6 eV, indicative of the presence of the stronger interaction between copper and carbon support [28,67]. The peaks at 909.9 and 916.6 eV in the Cu LMM Auger spectrum (Fig. 8b) distinguished Cu+ and Cu0, respectively. It was seen from the Table 6 that the order of the Cu° concentration in xCu/SAC varied with Cu loading, which was 0.3Cu/SAC < 1.0Cu/SAC < 0.5Cu/SAC. It is worth noting that the concentration of active Cu0 species in 0.5Cu/SAC (30.4%) was higher than that of 0.5Cu/AC (22.2%), indicating that more Cu0 active centers were created on the SAC support. 3.4 Discussions Previous studies have proved that the catalytic performance of carbon supported copper catalysts in the DMC synthesis were strongly depended on the surface Cu0 concentration [15,68]. In this study, the Cu/SAC catalysts with a very low Cu loading of 0.3–1.0 wt% even showed higher activity and stability than the high loading Cu/AC catalyst (5.6–10.0wt%) reported in a previous study [69,34], which considered to be attributed to the unique superiority for the SAC support. On one hand, confirmed by TEM, H2-TPR and H2-N2O titration results, it is convinced that the use of SAC to support ultra-low loading of copper gave rise to highly dispersed Cu NPs catalysts, which was mainly attributed to the super high surface area (2403 m2·g−1). In addition, the XPS results implied that continuous introduction of copper onto SAC support promoted the formation of more Cu0 species, and yet excessive copper caused larger NPs (Fig. 8) that difficult to be reduced by hydrogen atmosphere and consequently led to a decrease of Cu0 concentration in total Cu species, as determined by the TEM and XPS results. In one word, the high Cu dispersion as well as high active Cu0 concentration in the Cu/SAC catalysts afford the superior catalytic activity in the oxidative carbonylation of methanol. On the other hand, the 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst showed much better stability than 0.5Cu/AC after 5 cycling reactions, implying that the active Cu0 species distributed on the surface of SAC were more stable than on those on AC during the reaction process. Zhang et al. proved that the Cu dispersion was effectively promoted by OCGs on the AC support due to the enhancement of hydrophilicity [30]. Furthermore, the carboxyl functional groups were identified as anchoring sites for metal ions in the impregnation process, which could extraordinarily enhance the interaction between copper and SAC support and thus protect the NPs on carbon surface from agglomeration. According to the Boehm's titration results, SAC possessed abundant carboxyl functional groups and was about double as that of AC, which could enhance the interaction between Cu species and carbon support and therefore greatly improved the stability of the Cu/SAC catalysts in the DMC synthesis. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Cu/AC and Cu/SAC catalysts were synthesized by the impregnation method using commercial and self-made carbon materials as supports, respectively and investigated in the methanol oxidative carbonylation to DMC. As for Cu/SAC catalysts, the activity shows volcanic trend as the increasing Cu loading and 0.5Cu/SAC exhibits the most excellent catalytic performance with STYDMC of 316 mg·g−1·h−1 and TOF of 44.6 h−1, which is far superior than that of the high Cu loading catalysts (5.6–10.0 wt%). This could be associated with the high dispersion of Cu NPs caused by the high specific surface area (2403 m2·g−1) of SAC along with the ultra-low loading (0.3–1.0 wt%) of Cu species. In addition, the 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst showed far higher stability than 0.5Cu/AC even after 5 cycling reactions owing to stronger metal-support interaction derived from more abundant OCGs on the SAC than that of AC. These findings suggested that combined the large specific surface area with ultra-low loading synergistically can provide a convenient approach for highly efficient supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A series of copper catalysts with loading less than 1.0 wt% supported on super activated carbon (SAC, 2403 m2·g−1) as well as commercial activated carbon (AC, 1297 m2·g−1) were produced by the wet-impregnation process and applied in methanol oxidative carbonylation to generate dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The 0.5Cu/SAC catalyst showed highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles (NPs, ∼2.2 nm) and exhibited a turnover frequency (44.6 h−1) about four times higher than that of 0.5Cu/AC. The characterization results indicate that the large specific surface area of SAC greatly promoted the dispersion of Cu NPs. In addition, the abundant oxygen-containing groups on SAC enhanced interaction between Cu NPs and carbon support, which maintained the concentration of active Cu0 sites and facilitated high stability of Cu/SAC catalysts during the reaction. This research provided a novel strategy for fabricating low loading Cu-based catalysts with commercial prospects for the DMC synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient super activated carbon supported ultra-low loading copper catalyst for the oxidative carbonylation of methanol to dimethyl carbonate
